body.p: This topic contains reuable fragments for the installation topics. The reuse strategy is to ensure that key values can be edited and compared in one place. We reuse in big chunks as reusing highly granular pieces just makes things hard to edit without any real maintainability win. In some cases, content that fits in only one topic is still included here and conrefed into the topic to keep all the information, such as requirements, in one file for ease of editing.

section.title: Installation requirements reusables
section.p: In this section, the reusable element is the <dd> element of each <dlentry>. Where the requirement is the same across platform, there is one entry per requirement that is used in all platforms. Where there are different requirements per platform, the id of the reusable <dd> element is in the form requirement.platoform, for instance, "memory.windows".

dd.p: Installation packages are supplied in compressed archives. Ensure you have installed a suitable archive extraction utility with which to extract the archive. The MD5 sum is available at the Download page the Download page for every archive. You should check the MD5 sum of the downloaded archive with an MD5 checking tool available on your platform.This does not appear to be true of all platforms. The Windows installer is an EXE. The Linux is a shell script. And I'm pretty sure most platforms come with support for the typical archieve formats used on them built in, so I am not sure that this needs saying. If a reader downloaded a .zip file and did not know what to do with it, however, this topic does not give them enough information to figure it out. So this topic should either go away or be expanded.

requires Java to run. If you use the native Windows installer, will be installed with its own copy of Java. If you use the all platforms installer, your system must have a compatible Java virtual machine installed.
supports only official and stable Java Virtual Machines with the version number or later (the recommended version is 1.6.0) from Oracle, formerly Sun Microsystems (available at http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html). may work with JVM implementations from other vendors, but there is no guarantee that other implementations will work with future updates or releases. does not work with the GNU libgcj Java Virtual Machine.
To ensure that the correct version of Java is used:
Make sure that the PATH environment variable is set to the most current Java Virtual Machine installation.
Make sure that references to older Java Virtual Machine installations are removed from the PATH.
To specify a different Java Virtual Machine for to use, set the home folder of the desired Java Virtual Machine in one of the JAVA_HOME or JDK_HOME Windows variables. In case JAVA_HOME and JDK_HOME are not set, the launcher looks for a JVM installed in a standard location on your computer and uses it to start the application. If you use an installer that includes a Java Virtual Machine, rename or remove the jre subdirectory of the installation directory for the JAVA_HOME or JDK_HOME variables to take effect.This probably belongs in a troubleshooting topic.
